#Text=' 42-year detour ' ends : Garrison Keillor
#Text=homeward bound
#Text=Saturday , July 2 , 2016
#Text=Garrison Keillor , the humorist and longtime host of A Prairie Home Companion on US public radio network NPR , hung up his microphone this week .
#Text=The final episode of Companion to be hosted by Keillor was recorded yesterday at the Hollywood Bowl with 18,000 people in attendance .
#Text=It was broadcast today .
#Text=File photo of Garrison Keillor .
#Text=Image : Andrew Harrer / Bloomberg News / Landov .
#Text=Musician Chris Thile takes over as host in October .
#Text=Thile is expected to keep the program 's basic format intact while updating its content .
#Text=Keillor , 73 , created A Prairie Home Companion in 1974 , and it turned into a " 42-year detour " .
#Text=He had gone to Nashville , he said , " to write about the Grand Ole Opry for The New Yorker .

column1: #Text=All of these wonderful performers — Porter Wagoner was there , and Minnie Pearl , Roy Acuff .
#Text=They were all children of the Depression , and they felt so lucky to have whatever they had .
#Text=And it was really a happy place .
#Text=So I got seduced by that into trying to start my own show .

#Text=His on-air persona was a throwback ; a  radio bard " telling amusing stories spun from the fictional town of Lake Wobegon , Minnesota .

column1: #Text=Now , he says , that version of the Midwest " is receding in the rear-view mirror at high speed .
